Following the Second World War, Ruanda-Urundi was classified as a United Nations Trust Territory under Belgian administrative authority.  During the 1940s, a series of policies caused divisions throughout the country. On 4 October 1943, powers were split in the legislative division of Burundi's government between chiefdoms and lower chiefdoms. Chiefdoms were in charge of land, and lower sub-chiefdoms were established. Native authorities also had powers.  In 1948, Belgium allowed the region to form political parties.
